Uzone - A film will only be 1920x1080 IF it was shot in 16:9 aspect ratio like your TV is. Many widescreen films, are shot in 2.35:1 or 2.4:1 aspect ratios. So unless you want the sides of the film cropped off to fit your 16:9 TV, the picture fills your full 1920 width, and will be only 800-someodd pixels high. It's still "1080p" because it uses the full 1920 width.

The term 1080P means the film has 1080 lines of vertical resolution and that it's not interlaced. Has nothing to do with the horizontal resolution.

- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1080p

Anyways. I've got a 16:9 plasma TV set, so I can't playback any films with an aspect ration different than this. Due to possible image-retention etc.

Bad luck. :P

Well, yes, in the strictest sense of the phrase, 1080p means 1080 lines of vertical resolution. But in the real world any video with either the full 1080 vertical or 1920 width is "full HD", and your TV should display it fine with black bars on the top & bottom.

All consumer Plasma & LCD HDTVs are 16:9 (I also have a 50" plasma). A source doesn't need to be exactly 16:9 for you to play it. If you're choosing not to play films that aren't 16:9 due to fear of image retention, you're going to miss out on a lot. Image retention isn't an issue with Plasmas anymore, unless you're playing the movie on a 24-hour loop. Your TV will be fine letterboxing for a couple of hours for a movie.

Guess you're right on this.

But still, I wouldn't like to risk the panel for the first few days. It has only played about ~40 hours so far. Its' price was well over my monthly pay, so... I prefer being a little bit overcautious.

Image retention, or "image burn in", does NOT exist anymore. They fixed this issue using pixel manipulation techniques about 7 years ago, maybe longer.

Unless your plasma TV is OLD; like I mean REALLY REALLY old, then it will not have image retention. There isn't one single solitary television set produced today that has image retention. Period. It's a thing of the past.

You could go buy a plasma right now, open it, and immediately stick in a DVD and leave it on the menu for TWO YEARS STRAIGHT, and it would not retain the image. I've seen plasmas, LCD's, projo's, DLP's and CRT's all sit with DVD menus on for hours and hours day after day when I worked at Best Buy, not one of them retained an image. It's just impossible, the panel simply will not let it happen.

Play whatever you want, but it doesn't matter, you're not doing your plasma any favors by playing specific ratios.

1080p does not necessarily mean that it is 1920x1080, it just means that the there is 1080 horizontal lines if I am correct, an the p means that it is progressive and now you should also know that the i means interlaced.  1080p is the source including the black bars on the top and bottom of the screen.  Everybody just knows that it is going to be 1920, because that is the highest screen size for for HD.  What you are seeing in these videos is 800p, which means that there was black lines on the top and bottom of the video source, but it was cropped.

If anything that I said was wrong, could someone please correct me?  I think I got the part wrong about the 1080 horizontal lines.  Sorry if I am wrong about that or anything else.

Metroidn1f

The higher number in screen resolution is always the witdh for 16:9 & 4:3 displays. This is the ammount of vertical lines/pixels spanning the width of the display.nA 1080p source would include black bars and everything on screen from the source. Cropping a source is not a good idea, it can lead to all kinds of problems when the modified image is played back. I\'m on the search for an untouched 1080p version of this.

For those having problems with the files (ex; filesize 0kb's, unable to open...)
That is happening because of the total length of all the filename's are too long, so you need to rename your filenames to something smaller (and less: . - [!{ ... symbols in it)
At first I couldn't rename the files directly so I used a 30 day freeware program called: XYplorer (http://thepiratebay.org/search/XYplorer/0/7/0)
It's does many things and will also let you rename any file. 
ex: Rename: Harry.Potter.and.the.Sorcerers.Stone.2001.BluRay.1080p.DTS.x264.dxva-FraMeSToR
To: HP 2001 The Sorceres Stone
And voila, no more problems with the file (and it will also show you the properties this time ;) )
Enjoy.

If killercarvers method doesn't work;

At first I couldn't rename the files directly so I used a 30 day freeware program called: XYplorer (http://thepiratebay.org/search/XYplorer/0/7/0)

Okay, this is for everyone that is complaining that this is not 1080p.  Movies these days are usually shot in a 1.85:1 or 2.39:1 Aspect Ratio, so the picture its self can not have a height of 1080 unless you are a dumb ass and you want to stretch the video so everything either looks skinny or fat.  If your that person that is fine, you do it the wrong way, while we do it the right way.  People say that it is a 1080p rip, because the source is 1080p.  If you were to directly just rip the movie off of a blu ray disk, you would see that the picture size is 1920x1080 (If the blu ray is 1080p), but you will most likely see the black bars that are on the top and the bottom.  Most 1080p videos that you download crop off those annoying bars so you don't see them in previews and so it does not take up so much space when encoded.
